translated: Birth Stories🔽The Thirteen Group🔽The Chapter on Mangoes
The Birth Story of the Messenger
“I sent you a messenger, Brahmā,
to one meditating on the bank of the Ganges;
When asked, he did not reply,
is your suffering a secret?”
“If suffering should arise for you,
O Enlarger of the Kāsi Kingdom;
Do not tell him,

original: yo taṁ dukkhā na mocaye.🔽Yo tassa dukkhajātassa,
analyzed: yaḥ tam dukkhā na mocaye  yaḥ tassa dukkha jātassa
translated: who will not free you from suffering.🔽If someone were to free you from even a part
of that suffering of yours, even a single factor;
By means of the Dhamma,
then you may tell him.
The howls of jackals and birds
are well known;
But the howls of humans, O King,
are even more difficult to know.
Even if a person thinks
that someone is a relative, friend, or companion;
If, having been joyful before,
they turn hostile afterwards.
One who, when asked about their own suffering,
tells it at the wrong time;
Their friends rejoice in that,

original: Hitesino tassa dukhī bhavanti.🔽Kālañca ñatvāna tathāvidhassa,
analyzed: hita īsinaḥ tassa dukhī bhavanti  kālañca ñatvāna tathāvidhassa
translated: but those who wish them well suffer.🔽Knowing the time for one such as that,
knowing the single-minded intention of the wise;
The wise one should endure the sharp words of others,
And speak gentle words that are meaningful.
If one knows one's own strength is insufficient,

original: Na te hi mayhaṁ sukhāgamāya;🔽Ekova tibbāni saheyya dhīro,
analyzed: na te hi mayham sukha āgamāya  ekaḥ iva tibbāni saheyya dhīraḥ
translated: They are not for my happiness;🔽The wise one should endure the sharp words alone,
Respecting truth and shame.
Wandering in the country,
in towns and royal cities;
Begging for alms, great king,
for the sake of my teacher's wealth.
Householders, royal officials,
great wealthy brahmins;
I obtained seven treasures,
of gold, lord of the people;
They are lost to me, great king,
therefore I grieve greatly.
Those men, great king,
conceived in my mind;
Not able to free them from suffering,
therefore I did not speak to them.

analyzed: tvam ca khalu me mahā rāja
translated: But you, great king,
conceived in my mind;
Able to free them from suffering,
therefore I have informed you.
He was pleased with that,
the extender of the Kasi kingdom;
He deposited in gold,
fourteen times the weight of the gold.
The Birth Story of Dūta is the fifth.
